title: Welcome
text:
This reference book is a collection of insights into the immunoglobulin genes in the B cell repertoires of Rhesus macaques (RMs), based on the largest integrated dataset of antibody repertoire and long-read genomic sequencing data from 106 Indian-origin RMs. It explores the dynamics between known and novel alleles, as well as the relationship between expressed and genomic alleles.
The book provides:

A visual summary of alleles, categorized by gene types, , and Allele similarity Clusters (ASC).
A detailed allele table, including coding and non-coding region information such as RSS and leader sequences.
Interactive graphs and frequency distributions at the ASC level, enabling users to explore allele-specific thresholds, absolute frequencies, zygosity, genotyping summaries, and the relationship between expressed and genomic alleles, providing insights into repertoire diversity and allele selection.

With a user-friendly interface, the Reference Book enables in-depth exploration of IG data, facilitating research into allele distributions, relationships, and population-level variations in RM immune repertoires.
For more details, refer to the preprint: https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2025.01.07.631319v2

title: IGLV8-QYQW
text:
Allele Appearances
The plot visualizes the Frequencyand usage of alleles across a population as observed in both AIRR-seq and genomic data, focusing on alleles that meet strict criteria for inclusion in the genotype. Only sequences without mutations in the V region, with a single V allele assignment, and alignment starting at position one of the V germline were considered. For IGHD alleles, additional filtering ensured that sequences had no mutations in the D region and only one assigned D allele. Alleles were retained only if they had a z-score above 0, and for IGHD alleles, the median ratio of observed sequence length to allele length had to exceed 0.5. These stringent criteria ensured that the analysis included only reliable alleles.
The usage of each allele across the repertoires in which it appears.

Allele Appearances
The plot visualizes the Frequencyand usage of alleles across a population as observed in both AIRR-seq and genomic data, focusing on alleles that meet strict criteria for inclusion in the genotype. Only sequences without mutations in the V region, with a single V allele assignment, and alignment starting at position one of the V germline were considered. For IGHD alleles, additional filtering ensured that sequences had no mutations in the D region and only one assigned D allele. Alleles were retained only if they had a z-score above 0, and for IGHD alleles, the median ratio of observed sequence length to allele length had to exceed 0.5. These stringent criteria ensured that the analysis included only reliable alleles.
The usage of each allele across the repertoires in which it appears.

Only sequences without mutations in the V region, with a single V allele assignment, and alignment starting at position one of the V germline were considered. For IGHD alleles, additional filtering ensured that sequences had no mutations in the D region and only one assigned D allele. Alleles were retained only if they had a z-score above 0, and for IGHD alleles, the median ratio of observed sequence length to allele length had to exceed 0.5. These stringent criteria ensured that the analysis included only reliable alleles.

The plot visualizes the Frequencyand usage of alleles across a population as observed in both AIRR-seq and genomic data, focusing on alleles that meet strict criteria for inclusion in the genotype. Only sequences without mutations in the V region, with a single V allele assignment, and alignment starting at position one of the V germline were considered. For IGHD alleles, additional filtering ensured that sequences had no mutations in the D region and only one assigned D allele. Alleles were retained only if they had a z-score above 0, and for IGHD alleles, the median ratio of observed sequence length to allele length had to exceed 0.5. These stringent criteria ensured that the analysis included only reliable alleles.

title: IGHV0-YEGR
text:
Allele Appearances
The plot visualizes the Frequencyand usage of alleles across a population as observed in both AIRR-seq and genomic data, focusing on alleles that meet strict criteria for inclusion in the genotype. Only sequences without mutations in the V region, with a single V allele assignment, and alignment starting at position one of the V germline were considered. For IGHD alleles, additional filtering ensured that sequences had no mutations in the D region and only one assigned D allele. Alleles were retained only if they had a z-score above 0, and for IGHD alleles, the median ratio of observed sequence length to allele length had to exceed 0.5. These stringent criteria ensured that the analysis included only reliable alleles.

text:
Allele Appearances
The plot visualizes the Frequencyand usage of alleles across a population as observed in both AIRR-seq and genomic data, focusing on alleles that meet strict criteria for inclusion in the genotype. Only sequences without mutations in the V region, with a single V allele assignment, and alignment starting at position one of the V germline were considered. For IGHD alleles, additional filtering ensured that sequences had no mutations in the D region and only one assigned D allele. Alleles were retained only if they had a z-score above 0, and for IGHD alleles, the median ratio of observed sequence length to allele length had to exceed 0.5. These stringent criteria ensured that the analysis included only reliable alleles.

title: How to Read The Allele table?
text:
How to Read The Allele table?
The Allele Table provides a structured view of Rhesus Macaque (RM) immunoglobulin (IG) alleles, their characteristics, and their occurrence across different subjects and databases.
You can search for a specific value in any field using the search bar at the top of the table. The table will dynamically filter to display only the alleles that match your search query.








Chain – IG chain (e.g. IGH, IGL, IGK).
Gene Type – The gene type (e.g. IGHV)
ASC (Allele Similarity Clusters) – The name of the ASC to which this allele has been assigned.
Allele – The allele name (cluster name plus allele number).
Ig Label – The unique identifier assigned to the sequence of the core coding region (invariant should ASC assignment change).
Appears Also At – The other datasets where the allele appears with the names in each dataset.
Number of Combinations – Number of RSS/Leader sequence combinatons associated with this allele.
Seq – sequence of the core coding region.
seq_gapped - IMGT-gapped sequence of the core coding region (V-genes only).
5’ Heptamer – 5’ heptamer sequence.
5’ Nonamer –5’ nonamer sequence.
5’ Spacer – 5’ spacer sequence.
3’ Heptamer – 3’ heptamer sequence.
3’ Nonamer –3’ nonamer sequence.
3’ Spacer – 3’ spacer sequence.
l_part1 - Leader part 1 sequence (V-genes only).
l_part2 – Leader part 2 sequence (V-genes only).
Sample Count Genomic – Number of subjects where the allele is detected in genomic data.
Sample Count AIRRseq – Number of subjects where the allele is detected in AIRR-seq data.

title: How the Germline Set inffered?
text: A Genomic Germline Set (GGS) was constructed to serve as a reference for annotating AIRR-seq repertoire data. This set comprised high-confidence alleles identified from individualized reference sets, along with curated germline alleles from established databases. Alleles included in the GGS met stringent criteria, requiring strong genomic evidence and intact recombination signal sequences (RSS) to ensure functionality. Pseudogenes and alleles with incomplete RSS elements were excluded to maintain annotation accuracy.

title: How the Germline Set inffered?
text: A Genomic Germline Set (GGS) was constructed to serve as a reference for annotating AIRR-seq repertoire data. This set comprised high-confidence alleles identified from individualized reference sets, along with curated germline alleles from established databases. Alleles included in the GGS met stringent criteria, requiring strong genomic evidence and intact recombination signal sequences (RSS) to ensure functionality. Pseudogenes and alleles with incomplete RSS elements were excluded to maintain annotation accuracy.

title: How the Germline Set inffered?
text:
Repertoire Germline Set (RGS) Inference
For each subject, AIRR-seq repertoire data were annotated by aligning sequences against the individualized genomic reference set using IgBLAST. The GGS provided a reliable benchmark for allele assignments, facilitating the detection of both known and novel alleles. If an AIRR-seq-derived allele was absent from the GGS but met strict filtering criteria—such as being observed across multiple clonotypes with high sequence identity—it was flagged as a potential novel allele for further validation.
Repertoire Germline Set (RGS) inference, commonly known as genotype inference, was performed using stringent filtering criteria to identify alleles present in each subject’s naive repertoire. Only sequences that met strict quality control requirements were considered for RGS inference. Specifically, sequences were required to:

Exhibit no mutations within the V region
Have a single V allele assignment
Align to the V germline starting at position one

For IGHD RGS inference, additional criteria were applied to ensure accurate allele identification. Only sequences with unmutated D regions and a single assigned D allele were included.
